*: Prevented unit's Contents modification

Resolves #1514

The problem was caused by the [code optimization](https://github.com/coreos/fleet/pull/1376). Before that each unit was stored in its own variable. Then this code was optimized and units became stored in hash map (`getAllUnitsHashMap`). Each hash was assigned to the unit's pointer. And when template unit was checked by `requirements()` function, its content was modified by `values[i] = unitPrintf(v, *uni)` code. Once templated unit was modified, all related units (which have same hash) were modified too, because they are related to one pointer.

- move Monitor into server package

fleetd: protect access to global Server instance

There are three different paths in the main fleetd goroutine that can
access the global `srv` Server - reconfigurations, shutdowns and
statedumps. Right now there's nothing preventing racy access to this
instance, so introduce a mutex to protect it.

One potential issue with this is that it means that a reconfigure or
state dump can "block" a shutdown, but IMHO if this occurs it will
expose behaviour that is broken and needs to be fixed anyway.

server: centralise shutdown through Monitor

The Server has a global stop channel which is used both internally (by
Monitor) and externally (by the Stop method) to shut down the server.
This is bad; invoking the method simultaneously by multiple goroutines
is not safe (and as seen in #1044 can cause panics due to a
doubly-closed channel).

This change centralises the shutdown procedure through the Monitor, so
that when an external user of the Server wants to shut it down, it
triggers an error to propagate up from the monitor. Hence there is only
a single path in which the stopchannel (which terminates all other
Server goroutines) can be called.

engine/agent: change reconciler ticker behaviours

The engine/agent currently reconcile every $reconcileInterval,
irrespective of whether any reconcilations occurred for other reasons
(i.e. were triggered) within that period.

_after the previous reconciliation was triggered_. To accomplish this,
reset the ticker every time a reconciliation is about to commence.

fix(agent): Allow agents to bid on conflicting jobs

Agents may receive messages out of order, which can cause
an Agent to bid for a Job after it has already been scheduled.
If the job that was bid upon has conflicts, it can prevent
an Agent from placing legitimate bids in the future. Allowing
an Agent to bid knowing it could be bidding for conflicting
jobs will cause more churn during the scheduling process, but
at least it prevents Agents from sitting out of the bidding
process altogether.

fix(agent): Lock AgentState in event handlers

Access to the AgentState object by the Agent event
handlers must be done in a transaction. Locking from
the event handlers themselves gets us this. This cuts
down on mis-scheduling of jobs since Agents are no
longer dealing with a racy view of their state when
bidding on Jobs.

job.JobPayload is dead; long live unit.Unit

Previously, JobPayload was ostensibly an abstraction to allow Jobs to
support different kind of backends. However, it was never truly
abstract enough to support anything other than Units. This resulted in a
lot of glue code and inconsistencies in external and internal
interfaces.

This change completely rips out JobPayload and replaces most uses of it
with a slightly more robust Unit (essentially the two are collapsed).
There are also certain cases (e.g. signature verification) where it now
makes more sense for the object to be the Job rather than the Unit.

Finally, this change moves to storing all Units in the Registry by their
content rather than their name. Specifically it uses sha1 hashes of the
Unit's contents.

Basic backwards compatibility is supported for Jobs created with earlier
versions of fleet.

for running multiple copies of coreinit on a single logical server.

In order for Machine.BootId to be overridden at the coreinit.go
entrypoint, that value must be pushed through the entire system.

refactor(target): Wrap job payload in systemd unit file

* Reduce the amount of information a client has to provide when creating
  a job to the command that should be run. This allows us to change how
  we use systemd internally and offloads the work of forming a valid
  unit file from the client onto coreinit.
* Create a custom systemd target on startup. The name of the target is now
  generated from Machine.BootId so multiple copies of coreinit can run on
  a single logical server.

This is a partial fix for the bigger problem detailed in issue #13.

refactor(registry): Stop deleting globally-scheduled Jobs

will not be able to reschedule jobs that fail on any given Machine.
